At that time, a god whose radiance was twice as bright as usual came to where the Buddha was in the middle of the night. His majestic light was blazing, illuminating the entire Jeta Grove, making everything very bright.
At that time, the god bowed at the Buddha's feet, then sat to one side and spoke a verse, saying:
The gods and humans in the world, by eating and drinking, give rise to joy,
But in the world, there is nothing that does not bring joy when eaten and drunk.
At that time, the World-Honored One spoke a verse again, saying:
If there is one who can give with faith, causing the mind to be extremely pure,
In this world or the next, the blessings of food and drink will follow.
At that time, this god heard what the Buddha said and addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
It is truly rare!
You have well spoken this verse.
He further addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
I remember in the past, there was a king named Slow. That king gave food and drink at the four city gates, and also gave food and drink in the city and market.
At that time, the king's wife addressed the king, saying:
'The king is now making merit. Please allow us to assist the king in making merit.'
The king, hearing these words, took the food offered at the eastern gate and gave it to the queen.
The king's prince also said to his father:
Father and mother cultivate blessings, and I also delight in cultivating them.
The king, hearing these words, took the food offered at the southern gate and gave it to the prince.
The prime minister later said to the king:
The king now cultivates goodness, the queen and prince both cultivate meritorious deeds, I only wish that you would allow me to assist in cultivating meritorious deeds.
The king, hearing these words, took the food offered at the western gate and gave it to the prime minister.
At that time, the ministers again said to the king:
The queen, prince, and prime minister all cultivate meritorious virtues, and we now also delight in assisting in the cultivation.
The king, hearing these words, took the food offered at the northern gate and gave it to the ministers.
At that time, the people of the country again said to the king:
'The queen, prince, and prime minister are all cultivating merit. Please allow us to assist in cultivating meritorious deeds.'
Hearing their words, the king again gave the donations to the people.
Then the steward said to the king:

'The king's donations at the four city gates have all been given to the queen, prince, prime minister, ministers, and people of the country, cutting off the king's donations and emptying the treasury.'
The king replied:
'What was given before has already been given out, from now on, half of the tribute from the small neighboring countries will enter the treasury, and half will be used to cultivate merit.'
World-Honored One!

At that time, I cultivated merit for a long time. For a long time, I obtained excellent rewards, always feeling joy and happiness. The merit and rewards I received were inexhaustible, and I did not see an end to them.
As I have received, I attain great fruit and retribution, and only then do I know that the World-Honored One skillfully expounds this verse.
At that time, the Heavenly Son Slow-Mo, having heard what the Buddha said, rejoiced and leaped with joy. He bowed his head at the Buddha's feet and returned to his heavenly palace.

If a person has children and grandchildren, he will then give rise to joy.

Once, the Buddha was at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the Jeta Grove near ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
There are three kinds of untamed horses in the world, which all worldly people now know.ğŸ”½There may be a horse whose gait is swift but lacks good color; this is called incomplete as a mount.
There may also be a horse whose gait is swift and has good color, but this is also called incomplete as a mount.
Or there may be a good horse that walks and runs swiftly, but has a good color, this is called having completeness in riding.
People also have three kinds, like those three kinds of untamed horses.
These three kinds of people are presently known and seen in the Buddha's teachings.
What are the three?
There are people who have completeness in swiftness, but not completeness in color and riding.
Or there are people who have completeness in swiftness and completeness in color, but not completeness in riding.
Or there are people who have completeness in swiftness, completeness in color, and completeness in riding.
Which one has completeness in swiftness, but not completeness in color and riding?

It is like a person in the Dharma who truly knows suffering, truly knows the origin of suffering, truly knows the cessation of suffering, and truly knows the path leading to the cessation of suffering. Having such knowledge and insight, they cut off the three bonds, namely, the view of a real self, attachment to precepts and practices, and doubt.

Cutting off these three fetters, one attains the stage of stream-entry, does not fall into evil destinies, is determined on the path, and up to seven rebirths among humans and gods ends the cycle of suffering. This is called being fully endowed with speed.
What is meant by being incomplete in form?

If one is unable to skillfully explain the Abhidharma and Vinaya when questioned, is unable to comprehend profound questions, is unable to speak in accordance with the meaning of the phrases, and is unable to fully explain in accordance with the principles, this is called being incomplete in form.
What is meant by being incomplete in rideability?
Having little merit, wherever one is born, one lacks merit and does not obtain benefits, clothing, food and drink, bedding, or medicine. This is called being incomplete in rideability.
This is called being fully endowed with speed, being incomplete in form, and being incomplete in rideability.
What is meant by being fully endowed with speed, being complete in form, but incomplete in rideability?
What is meant by being fully endowed with speed?

A person who is in accordance with the Dharma truly knows suffering, truly knows the arising of suffering, truly knows the cessation of suffering, and truly knows the path to the cessation of suffering. Having known and seen this, he cuts off the three bonds, namely the view of the body as real, attachment to precepts and rituals, and doubt.

Having cut off the three bonds, he becomes a stream-enterer, does not fall into evil destinies, is determined in the path, and is reborn among humans and gods up to seven times, putting an end to suffering. This is called being fully endowed with speed.
What is meant by being fully endowed with color?

If one is able to skillfully explain the Abhidharma and Vinaya when questioned, with phrases and meanings corresponding, and to explain in accordance with principle, this is called being fully endowed with color.
What is meant by being fully endowed with vehicle?
Having little merit and virtue, one is unable to be born with great merit and virtue, and cannot obtain benefits, clothing, food and drink, bedding, or medicine.
This is called being fully endowed with speed and color, but not fully endowed with vehicle.
What is meant by being fully endowed with speed, color, and vehicle?
What is speed?
In this Dharma, one truly knows suffering, truly knows the arising of suffering, truly knows the cessation of suffering, and truly knows the path to the cessation of suffering.

Having known and seen this, one cuts off the three bonds and becomes a stream-enterer, taking rebirth among humans and gods seven times, not falling into evil destinies. This is called being fully endowed with speed.
What is meant by being fully endowed with color?

If one is able to explain and resolve questions on Abhidharma and Vinaya, with phrases and meanings in accord, and to expound in accordance with principle, this is called being fully endowed with color.
What is meant by being fully endowed with the vehicle?
If one has much merit and is born with blessings, able to obtain offerings of robes, food and drink, bedding, and medicine,
this is called being fully endowed with the vehicle. This is called being fully endowed with the third speed, color, and vehicle.
The bhiká¹£us, having heard the Buddha's teachings, joyfully undertook to follow them.

Once, the Buddha was staying at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the Jeta Grove near ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
In the world, there are three kinds of horses that are well-bred and well-trained.ğŸ”½There may be a horse that is fully endowed with speed but lacks good color and riding ability.

In the teachings of the Buddha, we can see and know that there are three kinds of people: some are fully endowed with speed but lack good color and riding ability.
Some are fully endowed with two but lack one.
Some are fully endowed with all three.
Who is fully endowed with one but lacks two?

In the Buddha's teachings, one truly knows suffering, truly knows the origin of suffering, truly knows the cessation of suffering, and truly knows the path to the cessation of suffering. One severs the five lower bonds and attains the state of a non-returner. Such a person does not return and does not fall into evil destinies.
What is meant by incomplete form?
If one is asked about Abhidharma and Vinaya but cannot explain them, and cannot speak in accordance with the principles of the phrases and meanings, this is called incomplete form.
What is meant by incomplete vehicle?
Having little merit and virtue, one is unable to be born with great merit and virtue, and cannot obtain benefits, clothing, food and drink, bedding, or medicine. This is called incomplete vehicle.
What is meant by the second, having two things complete and one incomplete?
This person, in the Buddha's teachings, sees the four noble truths and severs the five lower bonds, attaining the state of a non-returner.
If there are questions and challenges regarding Abhidharma and Vinaya, he is able to explain and expound them, the rest is as above.
If one is not complete, it is also as above. This is called the second, complete in two but lacking one.
What is the third, complete in three matters?

This person truly knows and sees the four noble truths in the Buddha's teachings, attains the state of anÄgÄmin, and so forth, and has much merit and gains offerings. This is called the third, complete in three matters.
When the bhiká¹£us heard the Buddha's teachings, they joyfully undertook to follow them.

Once, the Buddha was staying at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the Jeta Grove near ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:

the rest is as explained above.

They are fully endowed with all three things.
This person, in the Buddha's teachings, truly knows and sees the Four Noble Truths, and even has merit and can obtain offerings. This is called being endowed with the three things.
After the Buddha said this, the bhiká¹£us heard what the Buddha said, and joyfully undertook to follow it.
Thus have I heard:
Once, the Buddha was staying at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the Jeta Grove near ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, the Buddha told the bhiká¹£us:
Such three kinds of well-trained horses are suitable for kings and princes to ride.

Namely, those endowed with speed, color, and riding ability.

If a bhiká¹£u is endowed with the three things, he should be worshipped, made offerings to, and praised with palms joined. This is called being endowed with the three things.
What is meant by being endowed with color?
They fully uphold the precepts and are well able to protect the prÄtimoká¹£a, going and returning, entering and leaving, endowed with all dignified deportment.
In the face of minor offenses, they give rise to great fear, upholding the precepts with utmost firmness, without any transgression. This is called physical perfection.

Evil dharmas that have not yet arisen are prevented from arising, and evil dharmas that have already arisen are eliminated through skillful means.
Virtuous dharmas that have not yet arisen are skillfully caused to arise, and virtuous dharmas that have already arisen are skillfully caused to increase and expand.
This is called mental perfection.

If one truly knows and sees the Four Noble Truths in the Buddha's teachings, this is called swiftness of action.
After the Buddha spoke this, the bhiká¹£us heard what the Buddha said, and they joyfully undertook to follow it.

Once, the Buddha was staying at Anathapindika's Park in Jeta Grove, near Shravasti.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhikshus:
There are four kinds of horses that wise people should ride, which exist in the world.
What are the four?
The first kind, upon seeing the shadow of the raised whip, immediately becomes frightened and follows the charioteer's intention.

The second kind of horse, when touched by the whip, immediately becomes startled and frightened, in accordance with the intention of the rider.ğŸ”½The third kind of horse, when the whip touches its flesh, then becomes startled and frightened, following the intention of the rider.
The fourth kind of horse, when the whip pierces through the flesh and bone, then becomes startled and frightened, in accordance with the intention of the rider.
There are also four kinds of human mounts.
What are the four?
The first kind, hears that in other villages, men or women are afflicted by illness, are extremely ill, and are about to die.
Having heard this, deeply detests the worldly dharmas.
Because of this detestation, sincerely cultivates goodness. This is called a well-tamed human mount, like seeing the shadow of the whip, in accordance with the intention of the rider.
The second kind, sees in their own village, men or women who have contracted a serious illness, and eventually die.
Having seen this, one deeply gives rise to disgust and loathing.

Because of disgust and loathing, one diligently cultivates goodness with utmost sincerity. This is called the well-tamed vehicle of a man, like touching the body hair and pleasing the driver's intention.
The third type, although seeing that there are sick and dead people in their own village, does not give rise to disgust and loathing.
Seeing that their own relatives and close associates fall ill, become gravely ill, and eventually die, they are then able to give rise to a mind of disgust and loathing towards worldly affairs.
Because of disgust and loathing, they diligently cultivate wholesome conduct. This is called the well-tamed vehicle of a man, like touching the flesh and pleasing the driver's intention.
The fourth type, although seeing that their own relatives and close associates fall ill and die, still does not give rise to a mind of disgust and loathing.
Only when their own bodies fall ill, become gravely ill, experience great suffering, and feel extremely unhappy, are they then able to give rise to a mind of disgust and loathing.
Because of disgust, one cultivates wholesome practices. This is called the vehicle of a good and disciplined person, like seeing a whip touch the flesh and bones, following the driver's intention.
At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard what the Buddha said, and joyfully undertook to follow it.
Thus have I heard:
Once, the Buddha was staying at AnÄthapiá¹‡á¸ada's Park in the Jeta Grove near ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the bhiká¹£us:
There are eight kinds of horses in the world that are known and can be seen in the present.

What are the eight?ğŸ”½First, when a rider controls the reins and whip and is about to go on a long journey, that bad horse bites the bit, jumps and bounds, suddenly breaks free from the reins, destroys the riding equipment, and injures the body. This is called a horse's fault.
Second, when the rider mounts it, it refuses to move forward. That bad horse jumps and is uncontrollable, destroying the riding equipment.
The third one, when driven, refuses to stay on the road but only jumps into ditches and pits.
The fourth one, when ridden, refuses to move forward but instead goes back.
The fifth one, it is not at all afraid of the pain of the whip and goad of the rider.
The sixth one, when the horse-driver whips it with the whip, it rears up on its two front legs as a skillful means.
The seventh one, when the horse-driver intends to gallop, it instead lies down on the ground and refuses to move forward.
The eighth one, when the horse-driver intends to make it go, it instead stops.
In the Buddha Dharma, those who cultivate and study the Way also have these eight kinds of faults.
What are the eight?
If a bhiká¹£u has a matter of seeing, hearing, or suspecting with fellow practitioners of pure conduct, and it touches his own body, he immediately says to them:
'You are now young, ignorant, unskilled, and incomprehending. You should awaken and touch others, how can you want to awaken and touch me?
You yourself have faults and yet you bring up other matters.'
Such a person is like the first horse.
The second type sees other bhiká¹£us with offenses of seeing, hearing, or suspecting, and fellow practitioners of the precepts immediately tell them:
'You who have offenses, you have now committed such-and-such offenses.'
